issues.text: Whether the deduction of commission and royalties received from Dunlop UK from gross profits is justified as extraneous income without labour contribution?

anchor.surface_text: The first item that was challenged by Mr. Ramamurthi was regarding the deduction made by the company in the sum of Rs. 3,94,964 and Rs. 3,94,973 for the years 1962 and 1963 respectively as commission as well as the sums of Rs. 59,191 and 50,582 as royalties for the years 1962 and 1963 respectively received from Dunlop, United Kingdom.

issues.text: Whether return at 6% on share premium of Rs. 70 lakhs is allowable as return on paid-up capital?

anchor.surface_text: The company had claimed Rs. 4,20,000 for each of these years being return of 6% on the share premium of 70 lakhs. The company had also claimed a sum of Rs. 27 lakhs for each of these years being 6% return on ordinary share capital.

issues.text: Whether donations made out of profits, including to National Defence Fund, are deductible from gross profits?

anchor.surface_text: The third item relates to the deductions made, by the respondent out of the profits of two items of donations made in 1962. No donations were claimed as deduction in 1963.

issues.text: Whether the company's claim for 4% return on reserves employed as working capital has been properly proved and is allowable?

anchor.surface_text: The fourth item, which is contested by the appellant, is the return of 4% on reserves employed as working capital. The company claimed Rs. 23,35,009 and Rs. 24,90,563 as 4% return on reserves employed as working capital in 1962 and 1963 respectively.

issues.text: Whether the company's claim for rehabilitation is allowable as a deduction from available surplus?

anchor.surface_text: The fifth and the last item that is in controversy between the parties is the claim for rehabilitation made by the company.

issues.text: Whether the workmen are entitled to any additional bonus for the years 1962 and 1963 beyond what was already paid?

anchor.surface_text: This appeal, by special leave, by the workmen is against the award dated October 20, 1967, of the Industrial Tribunal, Madras, in I.D. No. 65 of 1966 in so far as it declined to grant additional bonus for the years 1962 and 1963.

arguments.claim: Commission/royalties extraneous like Hindustan Motors home delivery; Tata Oil distinguished.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the amounts received by the company, by way of commission and royalties, are analogous to the home delivery commission, which was held by this Court in Workmen of M S Hindustan Motors Ltd. v. MIS Hindustan Motors Ltd. Anr. to be extraneous income.

arguments.claim: Share premium qualifies for 6% return as capital per Companies Act Schedule VI; not undistributed profits.

anchor.surface_text: A capital introduced by the shareholders in the company is shown as part of share capital according to the Companies Act upto 1956. When the said Act was amended, it had to be shown in accordance with Schedule VI as a separate item, as it was only available for issue to shareholders and could not be distributed as dividend.

arguments.claim: Donations not deductible even to National Defence Fund per Voltas Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sen accepted that the deduction made by the management under this head is not justified. Even otherwise, the company is not entitled to deduct those amounts,- as is clear from the decision of this Court in Voltas Ltd. v. Its Workmen.

arguments.claim: Working capital return proved sufficiently; balance sheet alone insufficient but here affidavit/certificate/witnesses unchallenged.

anchor.surface_text: The position emerging from the decisions of this Court is that mere production of a balance-sheet by a company cannot be taken as proof of a claim, as to what portion of the reserves has been actually used as working capital. The utilisation of any amount from the reserves as working capital has to be proved by an employer by adducing proper evidence

arguments.claim: Rehabilitation not decided but even without, 60-66% bonus paid sufficient per Gannon Dunkerley proportion.

arguments.claim: Gratuities written back deduction not justified.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned that the company had deducted from the profits the provision made for retirement gratuities written back. Mr. Sen has quite fairly accepted that the deduction is not justified.

holdings.text: The Tribunal was justified in accepting the contention of the company that the amounts received as commission and royalties need not be added back to gross profits, as they are extraneous income without any contribution by labour.

anchor.surface_text: We are of the opinion that the Tribunal was justified in accepting the contention of the company that the amounts received as commission and royalties

holdings.reasoning_summary: Notes 1 & 2 in Ext. M-3 unchallenged; MW-1 evidence no cross-exam; analogous to home delivery commission in Hindustan Motors; distinguishes Tata Oil Mills as no labour contribution here.

holdings.text: The contention that no return should be allowed on the share premium amount has been rightly rejected; 6% return allowable as share premium is part of paid-up capital.

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied, in the circumstances, that the contention of the union that no return should be allowed on the share premium amount, has been rightly rejected

holdings.reasoning_summary: Share premium is capital introduced by shareholders per Companies Act (pre/post 1956 Schedule VI); not distributable as dividend; MW-1 evidence supports.

holdings.text: The company is not entitled to deduct donations from profits, even to National Defence Fund.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sen accepted that the deduction made by the management under this head is not justified. Even otherwise, the company is not entitled to deduct those amounts,- as is clear from the decision of this Court in Voltas Ltd. v. Its Workmen.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Counsel concession; follows Voltas Ltd. precedent prohibiting deduction of donations.

holdings.text: The Tribunal has rightly accepted the claim of the management for 4% return on reserves employed as working capital.

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that the Tribunal has rightly accepted the claim of the management for 4 return on the working capital.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ext. M-8, M-9, MW-1, MW-2 evidence filed; chartered accountant certificate; no cross-examination; satisfies Oriental Gas and Bareilly Electricity requirements beyond mere balance sheet.

holdings.text: Claim for rehabilitation not gone into as even without allowing it, bonus paid (66% in 1962, 60-62% in 1963) sufficient after tax rebate, per Gannon Dunkerley proportion.

anchor.surface_text: The fifth and the last item that is in controversy between the parties is the claim for rehabilitation made by the company.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unnecessary to decide; computations show sufficient allocation even excluding claim; evidence unchallenged before Tribunal but obiter as not required for outcome.

holdings.text: The award of the Tribunal holding that the workmen are not entitled to any additional bonus for 1962 and 1963 is correct; appeal dismissed.
